content.raw: I was not able to get this to run, and I suspect it is because the container is building against the default branch rather than against the gazebo9 branch. Assuming you want to build it against this branch, I’m not seeing how you did it. Is there some trick for setting the branch outside of the container?
content.html: I was not able to get this to run, and I suspect it is because the container is building against the default branch rather than against the gazebo9 branch. Assuming you want to build it against this branch, I’m not seeing how you did it. Is there some trick for setting the branch outside of the container?

content.raw:
Apologies, I mean “build” not “run.” Modifying the Dockerfile to switch to the correct branch resolves the problem. I can see this is kind of a Catch 22. Maybe there should be a comment in the file that you can uncomment to switch branches. I’d be interested to hear how you’ve been doing this.

In any case, it now builds correctly and runs on my machine with an Nvidia card. I will test the non-Nvidia version next.

One additional note which is more about Docker development--running multiple terminals to interact with Gazebo requires some non-obvious commands. I'm using `docker exec -it container_name /bin/bash`. Is that what you’ve been using?
content.html:
Apologies, I mean “build” not “run.” Modifying the Dockerfile to switch to the correct branch resolves the problem. I can see this is kind of a Catch 22. Maybe there should be a comment in the file that you can uncomment to switch branches. I’d be interested to hear how you’ve been doing this.

In any case, it now builds correctly and runs on my machine with an Nvidia card. I will test the non-Nvidia version next.

One additional note which is more about Docker development--running multiple terminals to interact with Gazebo requires some non-obvious commands. I'm using docker exec -it container_name /bin/bash. Is that what you’ve been using?

content.raw:
About multiple terminals in Docker:

* I added a script `join.bash` that you can call and will connect a separate terminal to an existing Docker.
* Alternatively, what you can do is:

    * `roslaunch ...`
    * Suspend the process: `CTRL-Z`
    * Resume and background the process: `bg`
    * Launch a second command. Eg.: `rostopic echo ...`
    * Kill it: `CTRL-C`
    * Bring roslaunch to foreground: `fg`
    * Kill it: `CTRL-C`
content.html:
About multiple terminals in Docker:

  • I added a script join.bash that you can call and will connect a separate terminal to an existing Docker.

  • Alternatively, what you can do is:

    • roslaunch ...
    • Suspend the process: CTRL-Z
    • Resume and background the process: bg
    • Launch a second command. Eg.: rostopic echo ...
    • Kill it: CTRL-C
    • Bring roslaunch to foreground: fg
    • Kill it: CTRL-C

content.raw: Got it. Thanks! This is making me think I could improve our docker setup when there is time after this release goes out.
content.html: Got it. Thanks! This is making me think I could improve our docker setup when there is time after this release goes out.

I see you just added a script that answers my question above by opening a new terminal in a container based on the image name it was created from, so I tested that too and it also worked well. Thanks!

I’m going to go ahead and approve. I assume we will wait for Brian to test and approve and then merge this after we have completed the other pending merge requests.
